Flavonoids have many nutritional-therapeutic and preservative features. Therefore, the aim of using them for fortifying food products could provide new horizon in developing new functional foods. However, there are several problems associated with the use of these phyto-active constituents in foods and food beverages. Nano-phytosome is one of the newest lipid based nano-carrier and fast growing attractive way of delivering botanical based nutraceuticals. Although the nano-phytosome technology has been developed for pharmaceutical applications, it could be potentially used in food products for designing novel functional foods and beverages. The current review represents physicochemical properties and potential applications of nano-phytosome as a carrier of food bioactive compounds in development of functional foods.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the industrialized world, people need to access their nutritional requirements more easily than before. Thus, people are growingly become conscious about their health, diet habit, and how to manage their time to prepare healthy foods. Therefore, the demand for functional foods, balanced low fat diet, the more natural, safe, and healthy foods that brings specific health benefits in less time is increasing steadily (Palzer, 2009). On the other hand, lowering fatty foods in the diet make deficiency of the necessary fat soluble compounds in the body. The word “nutraceutical” was first defined as a food-based compound, which provides health promoting benefits. These compounds include fat-soluble vitamins, carotenoids, phytostrols, poly-unsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), anthocyanins, flavonoids, and etc. (Nguemeni, Gouix, Bourourou, Heurteaux, & Blondeau, 2013). Nutraceuticals can be potentially used for enrichment of the low fat foods or producing functional foods. However, there are some problems such as their low solubility in an aqueous medium and their low stability during processing and storage (Tapas, Sakarkar, & Kakde, 2008). In this case researchers reported that nutraceuticals have less in vivo actions, poor bioavailability, and absorption due to their complex molecular structure (Bhattacharya, 2009; Pathak, 2011). Thus, using food grade nano-delivery systems for the encapsulation of nutraceuticals can be potentially a good solution for solving these problems.
The food-grade delivery system can be defined as the entrapment of a bioactive ingredient in a food grade carrier to protect and improve in controlling its release rate. Delivery systems could have various advantages in food industries as follows (Guzey & McClements, 2006; Pezeshky, Ghanbarzadeh, Hamishehkar, Moghadam, & Babazadeh, 2016; Rashidi & Khosravi-Darani, 2011; Sagalowicz & Leser, 2010; Weiss et al., 2008; Yang, Corona, Schubert, Reeder, & Henson, 2014):
– Protection of bioactive components from undesirable conditions during food processes and gastrointestinal conditions such as oxidation phenomena, pH, and enzymatic degradation; – Improvement the solubility of bioactive ingredients in an aqueous or lipophilic mediums; – Masking undesirable odors, flavors, and colors of some bioactive compounds generated during harsh processing and adverse storage; – Performs as a vehicle for controlling the release rate of the antioxidants and antimicrobial compounds for elimination or decreasing oxidation and microbial pollutions phenomena in the foods during food processes and storage until reaching to the consumers; – Improving the bioavailability of the encapsulated ingredients. – Food-grade carriers should meet all the following requirements (McClements & Rao, 2011; Tamjidi, Shahedi, Varshosaz, & Nasirpour, 2013; Weiss et al., 2008; Weiss, Takhistov, & McClements, 2006): – Their composition should be made up of safe and food grade components; – They should be stable against degradation during processing and storage time. – They should not have the adverse effects on the desired organoleptic properties of foods.
Delivery systems can be categorized in to the macro and nanodelivery systems. On the basis of nanotechnology definition, which is defined as production and manipulation of materials in the nano sized scale, nano delivery carriers have particle sizes smaller than 100 nm (Solans, Izquierdo, Nolla, Azemar, & Garcia-Celma, 2005). In the food and pharmaceutical sciences, it has been well documented that nanodelivery systems have superior functionalities than conventional microencapsulation systems. The nanodelivery systems have following advantages over macrodelivery systems (Hu, Tang, & Cui, 2004; Tariq et al., 2015; J Weiss, Gaysinsky, Davidson, & McClements, 2009; Weiss et al., 2006; Zur Mühlen, Schwarz, & Mehnert, 1998):
Nanodelivery colloidal systems are monodisperse or partiallymonodisperse solutions, which have thermodynamic and longtime kinetic stability. In contrast, macro-delivery colloidal systems are often polydisperse and contain relatively large particles (41 mm), which cause kinetically instability and break down over time. Nanodelivery systems provide more surface area in comparison to macro types and could potentially enhance the solubility (in hydrophobic or hydrophilic medium) and bioavailability of the bioactive materials. The nanoparticles at sizes lower than 100 nm shows high direct absorption at the mucus. Nanoscale colloidal carrier systems enhance releasing rate and targeting properties of the encapsulant due to their small and uniform size. Smaller than visible wavelengths of nanoparticles make them optically transparent. Thus, they do not adversely influence appearance of the enriched food beverages when adding them as the nutraceutical carriers. In contrast, macro ones have white opaque appearance due to the multiple light scattering.
Up to now, various nano-delivery systems such as emulsions (i.e. micro and nano-emulsions), nanoparticles (including solid lipid nanoparticles (SLN), nanostructured lipid carriers (NLC), and lipid nanocapsules (LNC)), vesicular carriers (such as liposomes, phytosomes, and niosomes) were introduced as the potential tools for fortification of food products (Fathi, Mozafari, & Mohebbi, 2012; Pezeshky et al., 2016).
Flavonoids belongs to the secondary plant phenolic compounds, which have remarkable antioxidant, chelating, and antimicrobial properties. Hence, they could have many beneficial effects in foods and health. There are large studies indicating a protective role of these compounds. They have the capability to prevent the low density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidation, and showed special cardio-protective effects (Bhattacharya, 2009; Yang et al., 2015). Having more flavonoid contents in the old men and postmenopausal women diet reduced coronary heart disease (Vinod et al., 2010). Some other studies have demonstrated that the consumption of catechin, a major flavonoid in tea, reduces ischemic heart disease (Pawar & Bhangale, 2015). All the health benefits of the flavonoids potentially enhanced by the application of nanotechnology. Nanodelivery systems can enhance the circulation time of the encapsulant and improve the bioactive compounds retention in tumor tissues, due to the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect (Maeda, 2001). Nanochemopreventive and anti-cancer effects of natural compounds such as curcumin, resveratrol, epigallocatechin-3-gallate, and other
nutraceuticals were investigated (Siddiqui, Adhami, Ahmad, & Mukhtar, 2010; Siddiqui, Sanna, Ahmad, Sechi, & Mukhtar, 2015; Signorelli & Ghidoni, 2005). Curcumin as the natural compound, has been shown to be cancer chemopreventive in several different tumors (Kostarelos et al., 2005). Curcumin-loaded liposomes showed better anti-prostate cancer activities than pure form due to the EPR effect. Treatment of prostate cancer cells with curcumin loaded nanoliposomes for 24–48 h showed at least 70–80% inhibition of cellular proliferation without affecting their viability. Albeit flavonoids have more health promoting features, enrichment of foods with these compounds associated with the following problems (Khan, Alexander, Ajazuddin, Saraf & Saraf, 2013; Shivanand & Kinjal, 2010; Sindhumol, Thomas, & PS, 2010; Tapas et al., 2008).
Some flavonoids are highly lipophilic compounds; hence it is not easy to add these functional ingredients to the aqueous foods; They are easily degraded during processing and shelf life and cause undesirable colors, odors, flavors and lose their antioxidant activity;
Although several herbal extracts and phyto-constituents have high in vitro bio-activity, they reveal less in vivo activities due to their poor lipophilic nature or large molecular structures or both, causing lower absorption and bioavailability (Ross & Kasum, 2002). Most of the biologically active constituents of plants, including most of flavonoids, are polar compounds or have affinity to the aqueous phase. Their poor lipid solubility restricts their aptitude to pass across lipid rich biological membranes. Moreover, their large molecular size (due to multiple phenolic rings) limits absorption from the intestine into the blood by a simple diffusion (Walle, 2004). Furthermore, it is probable that in the gastric conditions some multi-constituent herbal extracts are decomposed. The effectiveness of any herbal extracts and their phytoconstituents are dependent upon delivering an efficient level of them to the body. It is reported that using nanocarriers and complexion with some other useful nutrients potentially improve the physicochemical stability and bioavailability of these bioactive compounds (Vinod et al., 2010). Thus in this review we focused on phytosomes as a novel food grade-delivery system, which is more compatible with phytochemicals in comparison to the other delivery systems.
Phytosomes are a new type of herbal extract formulations, which have better absorption and enhanced bioavailability than the common plant extracts (Acharya, Parihar, & Acharya, 2011; Karimi et al., 2015). Bounding the herbal extract constituents to the phospholipids is the main interaction occurred in the production of phytosomes, which is also known as phyto-phospholipid complex. This interaction produces water and lipid soluble complex, which is the main advantage of phytosomes. Phytosome technology has been sufficiently enhanced the bioavailability of many herbal extracts such as silymarin (Amit, Tanwar, Rakesh, & Poojan, 2013; Yanyu, Yunmei, Zhipeng, & Qineng, 2006), curcumin (Zhang, Tang, Xu, & Li, 2013), Ginkgo biloba (Panda & Naik, 2014), ginseng, grape seed, green tea, and olive oil polyphenols (Kareparamban, Nikam, Jadhav, & Kadam, 2012). Thus this novel technology could be potentially developed for designing and producing of functional foods or dietary supplements. Therefore, this review aims to cover the potential application of nano-phytosomes, as the carrier of nutraceuticals, in food fortification.

sections.heading: 2. Structure of phytosomes
sections.text:
The phytosome consists of two terms; phyto and some. Phyto indicates that the bioactive portion of the complex originates from
plants and some implies that the final structure of complex have similarity to the cells. Phytosome complexes are compatible with lipophilic mediums. They have chemical structures similar to cell membranes and are considered as phyto-lipid delivery system (Bhosale, Patil, & Swami, 2015). The phytosomes are produced in non-polar solvent. This medium provides appropriate interactions between polyphenols and phospholipids (Guliani, Singla, Kumari, & Yadav, 2016). Formation of the phytosome is based on the hydrogen bonds (H-bonds), which is the main interaction occurred in phytosome structures. H-bonds are placed between the polar parts of the phospholipids (i.e. phosphate groups) and the polar sections of the bioactive substance. For example the formation of H-bonds between the hydroxyl parts of the catechin and the phosphate group of the phosphatidylcholine is the main interaction occurred in catechin loaded phytosomes (Kareparamban et al., 2012).
The phytosome structures have general similarity to liposomes when exposed to water. Mixing active ingredients with PC in specific ratios is the major step in the production of phytosome and liposomes (Patel, Tyagi, Patel, & Yadav, 2014). PC is miscible with both aqueous and lipophilic mediums. It is the principle molecular exist in cell membranes. Therefore, the main reason for using PC in the phytosome structure is the making the phytosome more similar to the cell membrane, which will cause rapid and easy absorption (Amit et al., 2013). Although liposomes and phytosomes have some similarities, there are differences between phytosome and liposome chemical structure. In liposome, no H-bond is formed between the polar group of phospholipid molecules and bioactive compounds. Instead of H-bonds the phospholipid molecules surrounds the bioactive compounds. On the other side, in phytosome, the phospholipid and the phyto-active components makes H-bonds to each other at the polar parts. The optimum molar ratios for this reaction is 1:1 or 2:1 (phospholipid: bioactive). These differences results in phytosome to have much better absorption and more bioavailability than liposomes (Semalty, Semalty, Rawat & Franceschi, 2010; Semalty, Semalty, Singh, & Rawat, 2010).
2.1. Phytosome ingredients
Phospholipids, phyto-active compounds, and solvents are three principle ingredients involved in the production of the phytosomes.
2.1.1. Phospholipids Nowadays industrially produced phospholipids are accessible. For this purpose the main sources are soya, sunflower, chicken eggs, and rapeseed (Suriyakala, Natarajan, Senthil Rajan, & Prabakaran, 2014). The phospholipids are comprised of a glycerol molecule linked to two fatty acids, and the third remaining site in glycerol is occupied by a phosphate group (El-Gazayerly, Makhlouf, Soelm, & Mohmoud, 2014). Phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), phosphatidylserine (PS) and PC (Suriyakala et al., 2014) are the major phospholipids that mostly used in the phytosome preparations. Among these phospholipids, PCs are used more than others. PCs are a group of phospholipids that include choline as a head
part (Fig. 1). The importance of PCs is attributed to their main role in the biological membranes. They are also fatty substances and a member of the lecithin with yellow to brown colors exist in plant and animal tissues. PC has dual benefits when using in the phytosome technology; (I) it acts as an appropriate carrier of the phyto-active encapsulant, and (II) it is a nutrient which has clinical effects in treatment of liver disease (Verma, Ram, Jha, Mishra, & Thakur, 2010).

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Phyto-active compounds (polyphenols)
sections.text:
Bioactive molecules are food compounds that have the biological activity additionally to their parent nutritional value. Polyphenols are the most constituents attend in the plant originated foods and consist of the major antioxidants. Fruits and natural beverages contain the main dietary sources of polyphenols (Arijit, Avik, Avijit, & Paromita, 2012). The polyphenol contents of different types of fruits varies between 200 and 300 mg per 100 g of fresh weight. Usually a cup of coffee or tea may contains around 100 mg polyphenols (El-Gazayerly et al., 2014). Herbal extracts are also very important source of polyphenols. Numerous polyphenols have been recognized from foods and herbal extracts. The three major categories of polyphenols are flavonoids, terpenoids, and phenolic acids (Amin & Bhat, 2012; Jain et al., 2010). Flavonoids are themselves distributed to: flavones (i.e. Luteolin), flavonols (i.e. rutin and quercetin), flavanols (i.e. catechin), flavanones (i.e. naringin and hesperetin), isoflavones (i.e. daidzein and genistein), proanthocyanidins and anthocyanins (i.e. cyaniding and pelargonidin). They have many useful roles in the parent fruit and in our diet (Shivanand & Kinjal, 2010). The main phenolic acids which present in many fruits and vegetables are caffeic acid (the major phenolic compound in coffee) and ferulic acid (the major phenolic compound in cereals) (Khan et al., 2013; Sindhumol et al., 2010; Tapas et al., 2008).
Polyphenols or extracts containing a large amount of polyphenols can be potentially used in food fortification (for nutritional and therapeutic applications) and preservation. However, separation and purification of them may cause loss of sufficient bioactivity of the purified compound. The chemical structure of polyphenols is relatively instability in food matrices and gastrointestinal conditions. The phytosome technology produces small cells which potentially protect them from destruction by environmental parameters (such as, oxygen, light, high temperatures, enzymes, and metals), digestive enzymes, and gut bacteria in gastrointestinal tract. Some of the polyphenolic compounds have high lipophilic nature and inadequate dissolution in aqueous foods and gastrointestinal fluids. Others are highly hydrophilic and are not able to cross the biological membranes. The phytosome carriers can potentially improve the solubility issues of lipophilic polyphenols in aqueous medium and transit of hydrophilic ones from water phase into the lipophilic environment then finally reaching the blood (Khan et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Solvent
sections.text: Up to now, the solvents used in the phytosome production, are almost aprotic solvents such as dioxane, acetone, methylene chloride, and ethyl acetate that are not food grade solvents (Maiti et al., 2005; Maiti, Mukherjee, Gantait, Saha, & Mukherjee, 2006; Sindhumol et al., 2010). This matter refers to the point that there are not sufficient works carried out on food-grade phytosomes. In order to produce the phytosomes for food applications, the food grade solvents such as ethanol can be used, although the number of such solvents is very limited.

sections.heading: 3. Application of nano-phytosomes in food formulations
sections.text:
Polyphenols can be potentially used as an antioxidant and
antimicrobial agents in foods and beverages. The phytosome has the safe composition (their ingredients are approved for food applications) and the manufacturing process is relatively simple, which cause to be potentially suitable carrier for polyphenols in food industries. The using of phytosome as a carrier of polyphenols for food fortification or preservation purposes could have the following advantages (Kareparamban et al., 2012; Khan et al., 2013; Singh, Parpani, Narke & Chavan, 2014):
Increase the stability of the lipophilic polyphenols in aqueous foods and beverages which cause to development of new functional foods; Reduce the adverse effects of polyphenols on the transparency and flavor of foods and beverages. Protection of polyphenols against degradation by environmental factors during food processing, storage, and gastrointestinal tract conditions; Improve the antioxidant and antimicrobial activity of polyphenols; Enhance the absorption and bioavailability of polyphenols, which leads to better nutritional and therapeutic effects; Dual functionality of phosphatidylcholine, makes the phytosomes more valuable structures.
For successful application of phytosome in food products, the food parameters should be considered. The pH of foods could influence the (in)stability of the phytosomes during storage time (Friedman & Jürgens, 2000). Ionic compounds such as PCs are pH sensitive and highly affected by the pH (Choi, Aditya, & Ko, 2014). Indeed, the pH sensitivity of phytosomes is the main disadvantages of phytosomes. Thus, food beverages with the neutral pH values such as milk is good candidate for food application of phytosomes. Another parameter is the particle size of phytosomes. It seems that the size of phytosome particles should be lower than 100 nm. This nano-scale size will grantee the non-significant effects of nanophytosomes on the turbidity and appearance of the fortified foods.

sections.heading: 4. Preparation methods of nano-phytosome
sections.text:
Phytosomes are fabricated by mixture of natural herbal extracts or pure bioactive compounds (i.e. flavonoids and terpenoids) in a nonpolar medium. Bioactives are linked to the phospholipids such as PC by the H-bonds from the polar sections. PC is an amphiphilic substance that has phosphatidyl and choline groups, which are lipophilic and hydrophilic moieties, respectively. The choline head of the PC is polar group and make links to phytoactive compounds, while the lipophilic and nonpolar phosphatidyl group, then wraps the choline-bioactive complex. It can be assumed that the cholinebioactive complex section is the body part of phytosome and the phosphatidyl group is the tail for enveloping the mixture. This phenomenon resulting micro spherical particles, which are as a cell-like compounds that is known as phytosomes (Amit, Ashawat, Shailendra & Swarnlata, 2007; Khan et al., 2013). Phytosomes are commonly produced by reaction of 3–2 mol (preferably with 1 mol) of natural or synthetic phospholipid, such as PC, with 1 mol of phytoactive compound in an aprotic organic solvent (Marena & Lampertico, 1991). Then, after creation of phytosome complex, it should be separated from solvent. For this purpose, there are various procedures such as vacuum drying in a vacuum evaporator, precipitation by an aliphatic hydrocarbon (i.e. n-hexane), lyophilisation by freeze dryer, and spray drying (Fig. 2) (Moscarella et al., 1993). For evaluating whether flavonoids are incorporated into the phytosome structures, the prepared complex should dissolve in chloroform, ethyl ether, or benzene. As flavonoids, in their
pure forms, are insoluble in these solvents, if there was any unincorporated flavonoid to the phytosome structure it can be seen by precipitation of flavonoids. While, they convert to be soluble after incorporating into the phytosomes. Hence, the phytosome generate a stable lipid compatible molecular complex (Franco & Bombardelli, 1998).

sections.heading: 5. Comparison of phytosome versus liposome
sections.text:
The structures of phytosome and liposome are shown in Fig. 3. The major differences between them are indicated as following (Maiti, Mukherjee, Gantait, Saha, & Mukherjee, 2007; Sindhumol et al., 2010):
Phytosome is formed by H-bonds between polyphenol and phospholipid. Thus, the bioactives make a link to the polar head of phospholipids, being an integrated part of the bio membrane. While, in liposome a large number of phospholipid molecules are assembled together. This molecular accumulation of phospholipids environs bioactive compounds without making any special links to them and the phyto-active is entrapped at the internal parts or between the layer membranes, regarding the hydrophilic or lipophilic nature of the bioactive compounds; The phytosomes reveals a better stability, bioavailability, and absorption than liposomes due to formation of stable H-bonds. In phytosome, the optimum molar ratios of phospholipid to phytoactive substance are 1:1 or 2:1. In liposomes, the molar ratio of phospholipids are usually 10 folds more than bioactive;

sections.heading: 6. Characterization of phytosomes
sections.text:
The physical characters of phytosomes are evaluated by shape, particle size, size distribution, nutraceutical entrapment capacity,
nutraceutical release rate, crystallinity, and melting point. The chemical composition characters are analyzed by spectroscopic and chromatographic techniques such as fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), and retention factor. For most of these studies a dry sample is required, which typically can be obtained from lyophilisation technique (Abdelwahed, Degobert, Stainmesse, & Fessi, 2006).

sections.heading: 7. Morphology studies
sections.text: Morphology of phytosomes can be carried out by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (Abdelwahed et al.) (Abdelwahed et al.), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) (El Maghraby, Williams, & Barry, 2000; Zhang et al., 2013). For this purpose, lyophilisation and also applying some drops of the phytosome samples on the aluminum foil (1 cm×cm) and letting them to dry in vacuum drier is another procedure for drying. Morphology studies are mostly used for observation of the particle size, entrapment behavior, surface attributes, and identifying the probable existence of impurities on the particle surfaces. At the TEM and SEM techniques some further treatments are required. For example, coating the samples with a very thin layer of gold is compulsory in SEM. The photomicrograph of phytosome surface mostly indicates that there are no crystalline structures or any impurities on surface area and the phytosomes are in spherical shape (Fig. 4) (Raju, Reddy, & Reddy, 2011; Zhang et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 7.1. Particle size, size distribution, and zeta potential
sections.text:
The particle size, size distribution, and zeta potential are parameters that could be analyzed by dynamic light scattering (DLS) and photon correlation spectroscopy (PCS) (Singh, Parpani, Narke, & Chavan, 2014).
The DLS technique provides particle sizes based on the Brownian motion measurements. It also indicates the distribution of particles by measuring poly dispersity index (PDI). Zeta potential is another parameter that could be very important in determination of phytosomes stability which also have effects on Brownian motion. The DLS is useful in determination of phytosomes’ zeta potential in order to evaluate their physical behaviors. The PCS technique is used for inspecting the phytosome sizes and endorsement the vesicular structure of final phytosome formulations. The PCS study mostly demonstrates that the hydration process in phytosomes often generate structures like unilamellar liposomes (Tripathy, Patel, Barob, & Naira, 2013).

8. Stability and entrapment efficiency of phytosomes
Analyzing particle size and structural integrity of phytosomes are the parameters that can be used for evaluating the stability of phytosomes at an appropriate time interval. The average particle size can be measured by particle size analyzers such as DLS and SEM and the changes in structural integrity can be observed by TEM (Bhosale et al., 2015). Structural integrity of phytosomes can also be monitored by assessing the entrapment efficiency. In another meaning, the amounts of nutraceutical leakage from the phytosome structure can be a suitable method for revealing how the structural integrity of phytosome is kept unchanged. The entrapment efficiency (EE %) describes the amounts of nutraceutical that linked and covered by phospholipid. EE % of phytosomes could be analyzed by the ultracentrifugation technique (Bhosale et al., 2015). For this purpose, the amounts of nutraceutical entrapped by phytosome can be quantified by extracting the phytosomes with an appropriate solvent followed by centrifugation. The centrifugation can be used in two ways; (I) higher rpm with short period or (II) a lower rpm with longer time. Then, the amounts of free nutraceutical (unloaded nutraceutical) in supernatant could be measured spectrophotometrically (UV–Vis) or chromatographic (such as HPLC) methods. sections.heading: 9. Thermal properties
sections.text:
Thermal properties of phytosomes including melting point and crystallization temperature can be analyzed by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). These properties mostly determined for confirming the presence of phyto-active compounds in the phytosome structure. DSC curves indicates the melting points of phytosome ingredients such as phospholipid, bioactive compound, and phytosome complex. The DSC curve of the phytosome noticeably vary from the DSC curves of individual and pure forms of phytosome ingredients, which illustrates that the chemical interactions between the bioactive substances and phospholipids are occurred (Singh et al., 2014). Formation of the phospholipid-polyphenol complex shows one endothermic peak in DSC curve. In this case, appearing two peaks implies that the phytosome complex does not fully generated and there are some simple physically mixtures of phospholipid-polyphenol in dried powder. The phytosome reveals a broad band peak with lower melting point of pure bioactive ingredient. While the nutraceutical and phospholipid moiety have different behaviors in DSC thermogram curves. The broad peak of phytosome implies the crystallinity loss. X ray diffraction (X-RD) technique is also another method for determination of crystallinity behavior. The XRD studies generally shows crystallinity loss of nutraceuticals peak, which endorses the chemical linking and entrapment of nutraceutical by the phospholipid.

sections.heading: 10. Phytosome for encapsulation of food-originated polyphenols
sections.text:
Up to now, almost all the studies about the phytosome have been on the pharmaceutical applications and products. Nevertheless, in the most of these researches, the plant origin food extracts, containing standard amount of polyphenols, have been used (Table 1). The most widely studied of extracts include olive
oil, fruit, and leave, grape seed, green tea, and bilberry extracts. Pure polyphenols such as curcumin, quercetin, hesperetin, and naringenin also have been used in phytosome formulations. These food-based phytosomes can be potentially used in food applications (if prepared by food grade ingredients) such as development of functional foods or using as natural antioxidant or preservative. The results of different studies show the phytosome has higher antioxidant activity and improved bioavailability than the pure form of nutraceutical at the same amount. The flavonoid types and their benefits of some of the plant origin food extracts are described in below:

sections.heading: 10.1. Green tea extract
sections.text: Unfermented green tea leaves have polyphenolic compounds such as flavonol groups, which are known as “green tea catechins”. Epigallocatechin is the most important member of this group. Numerous benefits such as antioxidant and anticancer properties, inhibitor of lipid oxidation, and weight loss activity are linked with them. The antioxidant activity of green tea is reported higher than vitamin C, vitamin E, and resveratrol (Amin & Bhat, 2012). Substances like Epigallocatechin, which increase caloric consumption could be regarded as weight loss agent. Epigallocatechin causes its weight loss effects by increasing thermo-genic reactions in the body (Di Pierro, Menghi, Barreca, Lucarelli, & Calandrelli, 2009).

sections.heading: 10.2. Olive leaves extract
sections.text: Olive leaf extracts have two major polyphenols; oleuropin and hydroxytyrosol. They play an important role in improvement of high density lipoprotein (HDL) and preventing the oxidation of low density lipoprotein (LDL), high antioxidant capacity, and antiinflammatory activity (Kareparamban et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 10.3. Grape seed extract
sections.text: epicatechin flavonoids, procyanidin, and proanthocyanidins are the main bioactive compounds in grape seed. Effects of phytosome technology is improving the antioxidant activity, reducing the ischemia induced damages in the heart, and protecting the cardiovascular system from oxidation residues (Jain et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 11. Spectroscopic and chromatographic evaluations
sections.text: The interactions between the polyphenols and the phospholipids to ensure and evaluate the formation of phytosome complex, could be analyzed by the following spectroscopic methods.

sections.heading: 11.1. NMR
sections.text: The H1NMR and C13NMR techniques have been applied in determination of phytosome complexes such as NMR spectra of catechin loaded phytosome (Bombardelli & Mustich, 1991) . H1NMR Spectra of different phytosomes indicates that the long tail moiety of phospholipid molecule (lipophilic part) does not participate in any chemical interactions and acts as a cover to envelope the central choline-bioactive complex (Li et al., 2015). The C13NMR is usually carried out for endorsement of the types of chemical interactions participated in phytosome complex (Tripathy et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 11.2. FT-IR
sections.text:
FT-IR is can be regarded as the easiest and simplest method for determination of phytosome complex formation. This method
compares the spectra of the individual ingredients, complex and their physical mixtures. In phytosome formation the free hydroxyl group of phyto-active compounds interact with the polar parts of phospholipid such as choline. Thus, appearing the broad peak instead of OH peak indicates the phytosome complex is generated truly. Stability of phytosomes and releasing rate of phyto-active compounds from phytosome structure can also be analyzed by FTIR. This can be carried out by inspection the spectra of phytosome ingredients (pure nutraceutical and phospholipid peaks) in an appropriate time intervals (Tripathy et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 11.3. Retention time
sections.text: Retention time in the chromatography methods such as high performance chromatography (HPLC) and retention factor in thin layer chromatography (TLC) is a simple method for characterization of Phytosome. Retention time/factor of phytosomes varied from the pure nutraceuticals and phospholipids. The difference in retention time/factors indicates the generation of a new complex which named phytosome (Singh et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 12. Future trends
sections.text: Although the use of nanodelivery systems could provide the discussed valuable properties, they might also encompass toxicological issues, mainly due to their size, shape, tissue accumulation, immunological reactions, and degradation substances (Bimbo, Peltonen, Hirvonen, & Santos, 2012). The composition of nanocarriers is an important factor. Nanocarriers must meat some initial principles such as composed of food grade components, to be considered for food applications. Another main issue in fortified foods is the safety of nanocarriers at the added level. Characterization of nanocarriers is a necessary part of understanding the capability of using these systems in food. For successful attempts, beside the nutritional assessments, the food processing parameters such as food appearance should be considered. The nanoscale dimension causes non-significant effects of nanocarriers on the turbidity and appearance of the fortified foods. In comparison to the other lipid based nanocarriers, nanophytosomes may provide better capability for fortification of food products. This is due to the composition of the phytosome. In fact, the other lipidic nanocarriers contain saturated lipids in their structure, which limit the application of them in food. Lecithin, as used in the synthesis of liposomes and phytosomes, is a natural compound commonly used in several applications, including food products, such as mayonnaise, and in these uses they are generally regarded as safe (GRAS) recommended by the food and drug administration (FDA) (Lecithin, 2001). There are sufficient reasons indicating that the phytosome is superior to the liposomes in structural integrity as discussed previously in this study. Easy production processes of the phytosomes is another reason for being more applicable in food science.

sections.heading: 13. Conclusion
sections.text:
Phytosomes are a class of lipid based vesicular carriers, which can be used for encapsulation of plant originated nutraceuticals such as polyphenols. Flavonoids are one of the main types of polyphenols and phyto-active compounds, which have several nutritional and therapeutic benefits. However, there are several problems, such as low stability and solubility, associated with the direct addition of polyphenols into the foods and beverages. Using the phytosome, as a novel food-grade delivery system, can potentially reduce these problems. Thus, phytosome technology can
be applied in development of the healthy and functional foods. Furthermore, flavonoids have the high antioxidant and antimicrobial properties and so that they can be used as natural preservative. Phytosome could increase preservation performance by protection of polyphenols against environmental destructive agents and controlling of their release.

referenceMentions.context: The nanodelivery systems have following advantages over macrodelivery systems (Hu, Tang, & Cui, 2004; Tariq et al., 2015; J Weiss, Gaysinsky, Davidson, & McClements, 2009; Weiss et al., 2006; Zur Mühlen, Schwarz, & Mehnert, 1998):

The nanodelivery systems have following advantages over macrodelivery systems (Hu, Tang, & Cui, 2004; Tariq et al., 2015; J Weiss, Gaysinsky, Davidson, & McClements, 2009; Weiss et al., 2006; Zur Mühlen, Schwarz, & Mehnert, 1998):

micro and nano-emulsions), nanoparticles (including solid lipid nanoparticles (SLN), nanostructured lipid carriers (NLC), and lipid nanocapsules (LNC)), vesicular carriers (such as liposomes, phytosomes, and niosomes) were introduced as the potential tools for fortification of food products (Fathi, Mozafari, & Mohebbi, 2012; Pezeshky et al., 2016).
They have the capability to prevent the low density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidation, and showed special cardio-protective effects (Bhattacharya, 2009; Yang et al., 2015).

metadata.abstractText: Flavonoids have many nutritional-therapeutic and preservative features. Therefore, the aim of using them for fortifying food products could provide new horizon in developing new functional foods. However, there are several problems associated with the use of these phyto-active constituents in foods and food beverages. Nano-phytosome is one of the newest lipid based nano-carrier and fast growing attractive way of delivering botanical based nutraceuticals. Although the nano-phytosome technology has been developed for pharmaceutical applications, it could be potentially used in food products for designing novel functional foods and beverages. The current review represents physicochemical properties and potential applications of nano-phytosome as a carrier of food bioactive compounds in development of functional foods. & 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
